      • flipped

        public static FloatBuffer flipped(FloatBuffer buffer)
        Calls FloatBuffer.duplicate(), flips the result, and returns it.

        This is a convenient way to get a flipped version of a buffer, without modifying the original buffer's position or limit.

      • ensureAdditionalCapacity

        public static FloatBuffer ensureAdditionalCapacity(FloatBuffer buffer,
                                                   int additionalFloats,
                                                   boolean deallocOldBuffer)
        If the supplied buffer has enough capacity to put the specified number of additional values (starting at its position), then the supplied buffer is returned.

        Otherwise, a new buffer is created, with enough capacity enough for the contents of the original buffer (up to its position) plus the specified number of additional values. The new buffer will be direct, and will have native byte ordering. The contents of the original buffer (up to its position) will be copied into the new buffer.

        If a new buffer is created, it may be created with a capacity larger than is required. This is useful for the common situation where, over and over again, a few values need to be appended, but we don't want to allocate a new buffer every single time.

      • ensureCapacity

        public static FloatBuffer ensureCapacity(FloatBuffer buffer,
                                         int minFloats,
                                         boolean deallocOldBuffer)
        If the supplied buffer has at least the specified capacity, then the supplied buffer is returned.

        Otherwise, a new buffer is created, with at least the specified capacity. The new buffer will be direct, and will have native byte ordering. The contents of the original buffer (up to its position) will be copied into the new buffer.

        If a new buffer is created, it may be created with a capacity larger than is required. This is useful for the common situation where, over and over again, a few values need to be appended, but we don't want to allocate a new buffer every single time.

      • ensureAdditionalCapacity

        public static ByteBuffer ensureAdditionalCapacity(ByteBuffer buffer,
                                                  int additionalBytes,
                                                  boolean deallocOldBuffer)
        If the supplied buffer has enough capacity to put the specified number of additional values (starting at its position), then the supplied buffer is returned.

        Otherwise, a new buffer is created, with enough capacity enough for the contents of the original buffer (up to its position) plus the specified number of additional values. The new buffer will be direct, and will have native byte ordering. The contents of the original buffer (up to its position) will be copied into the new buffer.

        If a new buffer is created, it may be created with a capacity larger than is required. This is useful for the common situation where, over and over again, a few values need to be appended, but we don't want to allocate a new buffer every single time.

      • ensureCapacity

        public static ByteBuffer ensureCapacity(ByteBuffer buffer,
                                        int minBytes,
                                        boolean deallocOldBuffer)
        If the supplied buffer has at least the specified capacity, then the supplied buffer is returned.

        Otherwise, a new buffer is created, with at least the specified capacity. The new buffer will be direct, and will have native byte ordering. The contents of the original buffer (up to its position) will be copied into the new buffer.

        If a new buffer is created, it may be created with a capacity larger than is required. This is useful for the common situation where, over and over again, a few values need to be appended, but we don't want to allocate a new buffer every single time.
